name: 3-phenoxyaniline
Reason: To predict the melting point of 3-phenoxyaniline, we will consider the effects of the functional groups and the overall structure relative to benzene. Benzene has a melting point of 5.5°C. First, we consider the aniline (phenylamine) group. Aniline on its own has a higher melting point (around -6°C) than benzene due to the presence of a nitrogen which can take part in hydrogen bonding, thus increasing intermolecular attractions. Adding to benzene, we might estimate this to add approximately +10°C due to hydrogen bonding capabilities. Next, the phenoxy group is generally a slight electron-withdrawing group due to the oxygen atom. When attached to an aromatic ring, it's likely to have a slight effect on melting point due to increased polarity and possible hydrogen bonding. We can estimate this increase to be around +15°C. Combining these effects, we start with benzene's melting point of 5.5°C and add the estimated increases for the functional groups.
